sub_title: Sr Researcher | Speaker | Landscape architect at Wageningen Environmental Research -Wageningen University & Research
summary:
"Working together on vibrant and resilient landscapes. Landscapes that evolve and landscapes that transform without losing intrinsic values and their natural basis. Landscapes that breath quality because they are loved and useful. Landscapes that reflect society and its needs. Landscapes that connect."

In more than 20 years of experience as a landscape architect, I have worked on a broad variety of assignments, in numerous areas and themes, in the Netherlands and abroad.

Considering that almost all societal challenges come together in the same spatial context, the landscape, my focus is on creating enabling environments at different scales together with all involved. That is why I specialized in creating enabling environments that offer opportunities and bring together the challenges, at different scales and always togther with all stakeholders.

I work on rooted and nature based solutions, climate adaptation and risk reduction, sustainable and resilient food systems and migration. Always from and with a spatial perspective.  

The heart of my approach is to connect, to innovate and to inspire.  By bringing people, knowledge, needs and desires together. Creating common understanding, building bridges and visualizing envisioned futures, via clear storylines and appealing visualisation.

With an open attitute, humor and passion. Creativity, flexibility, promptness and thoroughness, are words that characterise me well. I also bring in a strong sense for political and social relations, new developments and phenomena. I value direct actions and follow-up; hands-on by nature. From vision to implementation.

A shared, inspiring, activating story with a powerful spatial perspective, in which the natural system and the societal challenges come together and long term ambitions are connected to short term action perspectives; that will make the difference!

As such, we work together on a healthy, sustainable and resilient living environment, now and in the future!

Registered landscape architect (SBA Netherlands)
Member of NVTL (Dutch Association of Landscape Architects)

Country experience:
Netherlands, Belgium, Croatia, Russia, Ukraine, Turkey, Egypt, Swaziland, Mozambique, South Africa, Latvia, Bangladesh, Argentina, Uganda

awards.title: WUR Impact Award 2023
awards.description: Awarded for achievements and societal impact of The Netherlands in 2120

awards.title: NVTL Award 2022
awards.description: Achievement award for the future perspective A greener future for the Netherlands in 2120 (WUR, 2019)
awards.issuer: NVTL Nederlandse Vereniging voor Tuin- en Landschapsarchitectuur / Dutch Association of Landscape Architecture

awards.title: Green cube - Russian National Award on Landscape Architecture 2011 -Category Best Public conceptual design
awards.description:
At the Second Exhibition Forum on Architecture, Landscape Architecture and Garden Art (2011) Moscow, the project Green River Project Brateevo has been awarded with the Russian National Award on Landscape Architecture. 

The project was a joint cooperation between Russia and the Netherlands. Supported by the Dutch Government and the Department for Natural Resource Management and Environmental Protection of Moscow, the Dutch Government Service for Land and Water management (DLG), together with the Dutch consultancy OKRA landscape architects, the Russian consultancy Ampir landscape architects and the Research and Design Institute for the Master Plan of Moscow worked on the development and exchange of ideas for a sustainable cityscape. Objective was to develop a toolkit for sustainable green development as an integral part of urban redevelopment.
awards.issuer: Association of Landscape Architects of Russia, the Moscow Alliance of Landscape Architects, the Union of Architects of Russia and the Union of Moscow Architects

awards.title: Gouden Oorkonde Federatie Behoudt de Langstraatspoorbruggen
awards.description: The Federation Conservation Railwaybridges Langstraat awarded in February 2006 nine persons for their contribution in stimulating bicycle traffic and protection of heritage. Among others, also the Commissioner for the Queen, Ms. Maij Weggen, artist Kees van Spijk and alderman of the city of Waalwijk, Mr. Bleekendaal.

projects.title: Imagine Food Systems 2100: a diverse, healthy and just food future for Europe (and beyond) (KB-35-103-003)
projects.description:
Imagine a just and diverse European food system based on social and ecological justice, planetary and human health, what would such a system look like? 

NL2120 has shown that really rethink systems and bring an integrated and positive narrative to the forefront is key in mobilising society in transition. In this project we will‘collectively paint (co-creating) Europe’s future food picture’, in which the process of painting is perhaps more important than the ‘final’ painting itself . It is a process where people bring in knowledge and wishes to develop a future that THEY would like to live in. We depart from the belief that nature and ecosystem health is crucial for food systems and demands the need for nature-based solutions. From there we propose to paint Europe’s food future 2100 on the following three core values: just, healthy and diverse. The painting will be done with the next generation and experts from Wageningen University & Research and aims to set the agenda to really rethink our food system.

contributors.headline: Sr Researcher | Speaker | Landscape architect at Wageningen Environmental Research -Wageningen University & Research
Head of Program Green Cities (and Regions) | Wageningen University & Research | Nature-based solutions | Just transition | Food Hubs | Author | Speaker | Optimist |

projects.title: Expanding and enhancing nature based strategies to shape a climate and future proof society - NBS boost (KB-36-007-002)
projects.description:
In 2019, Wageningen University & Research published a long term vision for a nature based future of the Netherlands in 2120 (NL212). This perspective proved to be appealing to national, regional and local policy makers, the private sector and across society. The vision was one of the frontrunners and boosted a shift in thinking about the connected transitions and the way to act. Since the publication the vision has been further propagated and to developed to action perspectives and regional and local visions based on the ideas, beliefs and principles of NL2120.    

With NBS Boost, we  are going to build further together on the results and insight gained and expand, enhance and enrich the integrated insights and knowledge required for a transition to a nature based future, for the Netherlands and beyond. Within this project the Mansholt Lecture 2023 (https://www.wur.nl/en/calendar-1/mansholt-lecture.htm) will be created in a co-creative way: towards EU2120.

projects.title: Food & nutrition security for low-income groups in rural-urban food systems
projects.description:
Many developing countries are rapidly urbanising. Informal settlements (slums) are expanding. The extent of undernutrition and access to healthy food depends on links to rural areas. Working with local actors, we will develop strategic interventions and practical solutions aimed at improving food security and improving the sustainability of rural-urban connections in food systems. 
Identifying effective interventions requires a broad understanding of all of the components of the food system, and of the socio-economic, natural and spatial context of the food system. More than anything, it calls for a contextual understanding of the complex interactions between food system actors. 

This research will build on the ‘rural-urban food system approach’ with co-creation methods used to develop systemic, social and technical innovations. The outcomes of the system and possible interventions will be evaluated in terms of food security, and using socio-economic, environmental and climate indicators.

More info: https://www.wur.nl/en/research-results/research-funded-by-the-ministry-of-lnv/expertisegebieden/kennisonline/food-nutrition-security-for-low-income-groups-in-rural-urban-food-systems-1.htm

projects.title: Nature Positive Food Systems (KB-35-101-003)
projects.description:
he transition to a nature-positive food system requires integrated and coordinated action by all actors involved to develop new solutions. This requires not just a shared recognition of the urgency of nature-positive food systems, but also agreement on what the pathways to such systems will be, and the tools and solutions needed.

The transition to a nature-positive food system calls for a paradigm shift and will depend on the social and spatial context the system operates in, and on coming to an agreement about the type of action to be taken. We believe that the most successful nature-positive food systems are those that are supported by an integrated approach and by collaboration. 

In this project we will develop a further understanding of nature positive food systems, a methodology and building blocks to help reveal existing knowledge while also generating complementary knowledge to help us arrive at more transparent and sustainable decisions regarding nature-positive food systems.

More info: https://www.wur.nl/en/research-results/research-funded-by-the-ministry-of-lnv/expertisegebieden/kennisonline/nature-positive-food-systems-1.htm

projects.title: Social-ecological Transformation for bottom-UP Integrated Approach in Caribbean Landscapes (TRUPIAL) (KB-36-008-002)
projects.description:
There is a growing consensus that conservation efforts alone are not enough to achieve healthy nature; nature must be integrated into sectoral planning from the outset, rather than mitigating potential negative effects afterwards. This concept of 'nature-inclusiveness' emphasizes the integration of nature considerations into cross-sectoral planning processes, policies, standards, and regulations. Nature-inclusiveness needs to be embedded not only at the institutional level but also in the informal culture and processes of government offices. This project aims to strengthen nature by mainstreaming it in sectoral perspectives and building upon small local bottom-up initiatives. Participatory methodologies are used to understand how these initiatives can be strengthened and connected to ongoing policy dialogues, allowing the 'seeds of change' to grow and propagate.

More info: https://research.wur.nl/en/projects/32-social-ecological-transformation-for-bottom-up-integrated-appr

projects.title: Soil and water shaping our world
projects.description:
Soil and water form the very basis of our society and economy. However, the choices we have made in land use and spatial planning came with trade offs to these important systems. As such, due to climate change and biodiversity loss, we are now facing the effects and boundaries. 
In this project we explore how soil and water can help us shape our world and how future choices in spatial planning, society and economy, based on soil and water, can regenerate these same import basic systems again. Working on a clear understanding of the complexity and the possible choices and consequences.

projects.title: PPP Participation and co-creation Knowledge region at Sea 2070: climate adapation and the next generation
projects.description: In this public private partnership (PPS) in which the municipalities of The Hague, Delft, Leiden and Zoetermeer join forces with Wageningen University and Research, the museum Omniversum/Museon, the Dutch State Forestry and the National Park Hollandse Duinen to develop new methods, processes and cooperation to better involve the next generation in nature based futures and climate adaptation. The aim is to really get the next generation (primary school and middle school) in the drivers' seat and discover how they look at the future and the actions needed. Part of this project is  a mobile exhibition, a tailored interactive curriculum and co-creative activities.

projects.title: BO Aan de slag voor een duurzame toekomst op hoge zandgronden (BO-43-101-076 Sustainable futures for sandy soil areas in the Netherlands)
projects.description:
Het rijksbeleid werkt naar een gebiedsgerichte, integrale aanpak van de opgaven rond stikstof, biodiversiteit, klimaatmitigatie, klimaatadaptatie en waterkwaliteit, met nadrukkelijke aandacht voor het perspectief van de landbouw en met het natuurlijke bodem- en watersysteem als leidend principe. Dit onderzoek probeert dit voor de hoge zandgronden te vertalen naar passende langetermijnvisies en concreet handelingsperspectie voor de kortetermijn, waar de geschetste opgaven heel nadrukkelijk samen komen. 

Meer informatie: https://www.wur.nl/nl/onderzoek-resultaten/onderzoeksprojecten-lnv/soorten-onderzoek/kennisonline/aan-de-slag-voor-een-duurzame-toekomst-op-hoge-zandgronden-doorsnijdend.htm

The current Dutch National policy is working towards an area-oriented, integrated approach which brings together solutions for several challenges: nitrogen, biodiversity, climate mitigation, climate adaptation and water quality, with explicit attention to the perspective of agriculture and taking the natural soil and water system as the guiding principle. This research translates this into suitable long-term visions and concrete action perspectives for the sandy soil areas of the Netherlands.

contributors.headline: Sr Researcher | Speaker | Landscape architect at Wageningen Environmental Research -Wageningen University & Research
Projectleider Bodem en Water Sturend bij Wageningen Environmental Research

projects.title: A nature-based future for the Netherlands in 2120 | Een natuurlijkere toekomst voor Nederland in 2120  (KB-36-003-004)
projects.description:
The Netherlands stands for large transitions to make the country future proof. The energy transition, reform of agriculture, expansion and extention of food production at sea, urbanisation and the adaptation to climate change are major challenges. Major challenges that each on their own, but also in  interaction, have large impact on the spatial organisation of the Netherlands. 

The aim of this project is to develop an inspiring vision on a future proof spatial organisation for the Netherlands in the perspective of the big societal transitions (energy, adaptation, circular economy and urbanization). Creating opportunities for nature and biodiversity and the use of natural processes (nature based solutions) are key.  

Nederland staat voor grote transities om ons land toekomstbestendig te maken. De energietransitie, hervorming van de landbouw, uitbreiding van voedselproductie op zee, de verstedelijking en het aanpassen aan het veranderende klimaat zijn opgaven die stuk voor stuk impact gaan hebben op de inrichting van Nederland. 

Het doel van dit project is het ontwikkelen van een inspirerende visie voor een toekomstbestendige inrichting van Nederland in het licht van grote maatschappelijke transities (energie, adaptatie, circulaire economie, verstedelijking) waarbij het creëren van kansen voor natuur en biodiversiteit en het benutten van natuurlijke processen het uitgangspunt is.

contributors.headline: Sr Researcher | Speaker | Landscape architect at Wageningen Environmental Research -Wageningen University & Research

projects.title: Changing Routes: migration and the environment
projects.description:
In the past decade, global displacement due to sudden (natural) disasters, crises and slow onset events has reached record levels. Numbers will increase even further, also because of ongoing climate change and related extreme natural events. The challenge for the future is to make sure existing systems and structures in emergency assistance and disaster relief are able to cope with this development. 

The complex challenges related to migration will benefit from an integrated, holistic approach. Wageningen University & Research combines different fields of expertise that address cross-cutting themes, such as Climate Change, Sustainability, Environment, Security and Health.

contributors.headline: Sr Researcher | Speaker | Landscape architect at Wageningen Environmental Research -Wageningen University & Research

projects.title: Wageningen Fire Center
projects.description:
Developing interdisciplinary knowledge platform on Wild(land) Fires. 

Bringing together experts and expertise within Wageningen UR and our network partners, regarding the different aspects of wild(land) fires connected to the in-depth knowledge of Wageningen UR an the natural environment. From the basics (soil, ecology, forestry) to drivers (i.e climate), impacts (on the environment, the surroundings, the economy and society) towards (nature based) solutions (spatial planning, tools and measures); offering an integrative approach.

contributors.headline: Sr Researcher | Speaker | Landscape architect at Wageningen Environmental Research -Wageningen University & Research
Assistant Professor, Soil Geography and Landscape Group at Wageningen University

projects.title: Feeding Cities and Migration
projects.description:
Cities all over the globe are growing substantially and are becoming more and more complex.  To provide everybody with enough and sufficient, healthy food a robust and sustainable food system is essential. 

Within this project, several research institutes are working together to find suitable approaches, methods and to develop strategic interventions and solutions, together with relevant stakeholders. 

The aim is to provide a better insight of urban food systems to come to sustainable, resilient urban food systems, with special attention for the impact of migration on food security. The Nexus Water-Food-Energy-Ecosystem plays an important central role within. 

Steden over de hele wereld worden steeds groter en in logistieke en bestuurlijke zin complexer. Om iedereen voldoende en gezond voedsel te kunnen bieden is een robuust en duurzaam voedselsysteem nodig.

Binnen dit project werken diverse kennisinstituten samen om passende benaderingen, methoden en bovenal strategische interventies en oplossingen te ontwikkelen samen met relevante stakeholders. Doel is om beter inzicht in en daarmee beter grip op stedelijke voedselsystemen te krijgen, met bijzondere aandacht voor de invloed van migratie op voedselzekerheid, om te komen tot duurzame, veerkrachtige stedelijke voedselsystemen. De Nexus Water-Voedsel-Energie-Ecosysteem speelt daarbij een belangrijke rol.

contributors.headline: Sr Researcher | Speaker | Landscape architect at Wageningen Environmental Research -Wageningen University & Research

projects.title: Just Transition: scientific base for bringing the principles into practice
projects.description:
Just transition is at the core of many policy documents, in the Netherlands, at the European level as well as international policy documents. But what does it mean? How to make sure that transitions are just? And just for who? This project helps policymakers to operationalise just transition by collecting scientific evidence.

In the KB project Just Transitions we aim to collect scientific evidence to support the development of an operational framework and approach to put just transition into practice.

contributors.headline: Sr Researcher | Speaker | Landscape architect at Wageningen Environmental Research -Wageningen University & Research

projects.title: Water Management Knowledge & Innovation Program (WMKIP) for the Southern Coastal Region of Bangladesh
projects.description:
To improve the welfare and livelihood activities of local communities in the Western Coast of Bangladesh by developing innovations and knowledge on water management Deltares and the Institute of Water Modelling (IWM), with the collaboration of  Wageningen University & Research and other partners,  have joined forces for “The Water Management Knowledge and Innovation Programme” (WMKIP). The program is funded by the Embassy of the Kingdom of the Netherlands in Bangladesh. It started in December 2017 and will have three years of duration.

The goal of this programme to contribute to the Long Term Development Goals for the Southern Coastal Region and Objectives of the Blue Gold program through tested and sustainable water management innovations, knowledge development and participatory action research.

projects.title: De Grenzeloze 8RHK
projects.description: This project aims at unravelling the way to true integrated planning, based on common understanding of the natural system and the way forward to bring transitions and major challenges together.

projects.title: Grenzeloze 8RHK -preverkenning NPLG
projects.description:
In het kader van het vorm te geven Nationaal Programma Landelijk Gebied is door Wageningen
Environmental Research samen met Rijk, provincie en de regio 8RHK een preverkenning uitgevoerd.
De preverkenning heeft als doel om een basis te leggen voor een gedeelde aanpak, waarbij inzicht in
de samenhang en complexiteit van de opgaven én het natuurlijk systeem centraal staan. De
preverkenning laat zien dat een gedeeld begrip van het natuurlijk systeem en de relaties,
dwarsverbanden en ruimtelijke vertaling van de transities en opgaven het gezamenlijk vertrekpunt
moet zijn. In een mogelijk gezamenlijk vervolgproces kan hier nader invulling aan worden gegeven.

contributors.headline: Sr Researcher | Speaker | Landscape architect at Wageningen Environmental Research -Wageningen University & Research

projects.title: Kennisregio aan Zee 2070 (Knowledge Region at Sea 2070)
projects.description:
Kennisregio aan Zee 2070 is an exploration towards a future perspective for the Knowledge Region at Sea (Den Haag, Delft, Leiden, Zoetermeer) in which the natural basis forms the starting point for the major transitions and development of this region. It serves as a basis for a joint action and knowledge program.  

The perspective is a cooperation of Wageningen University & Research, the Technical University of Delft, Leiden University and Haagse Hogeschool with the municipalities of Den Haag, Leiden, Delft and Zoetermeer and State Forestry (Staatsbosbeheer).

authors.headline: Sr Researcher | Speaker | Landscape architect at Wageningen Environmental Research -Wageningen University & Research
Author | Speaker | Program Leader Green Climate Solutions @ Wageningen Environmental Research

profile_positions.description:
As senior researcher at Wageningen Environmental Research, I work on the further development, understanding and application of Research by Design in different research topics, together with Michael van Buuren and Xiaolu Hu. 

Personally, my work focuses on the domains of climate adaptation and climate change governance, disaster risk reduction and migration. In these domains I bring in a clear conceptual, strategic and operational spatial perspective. Working on common understanding, integrative strategies and practical solutions based on the values of creativity, co-creation and spatial planning 

Consider, almost all societal challenges come together in the same spatial context, our landscape. It’s our responsibility to make it work in the most optimal and qualitative way. 

We provide and apply different design methods and tools in the different projects and research programs of Wageningen Environmental Research (WENR). Offering a creative and integrative view and using the power of visualization and participation, from concept development to spatial strategies and implementation. Enhancing science for impact. We bring in practical and strategic experience gained in national and international projects in consultancy and executive government. The integrative view and spatial focus of the landscape architect, combined with the excellent knowledge, expertise and networks at WENR adds true value to each project. We enjoy tackling (spatial) challenges together with partners and stakeholders, discovering the most suitable approaches and innovative solutions. Consider this as an invitation.
 
Wageningen Environmental Research contributes by qualified and independent research to the realisation of a high quality and sustainable green living environment. It offers a combination of practical, innovative and interdisciplinary scientific research across many disciplines related to the green world around us and the sustainable use of our living environment.
profile_positions.title: Senior Researcher / Landscape architect

profile_positions.description:
In my role as senior advisor Spatial Design and Planning, I have worked on a broad range of assignments, widely varying in scale, theme and place. Mainly involved in integrated, complex issues and interactive planning based on a strong governance strategy, not only in the Dutch context but also in an international perspective. From vision towards implementation. 

Among others, the core themes were land consolidation, rural development, agriculture, nature development, ecosystem services, green and the city, energy transition and sustainable development. Examples vary from developments in Brainport Eindhoven, Zuidwestelijke Delta, Greenport Venlo, Brabantse Wal and De Beerze in the Netherlands, to international projects in Turkey, Egypt, Russia, Ukraine, Latvia, Croatia, Swaziland and Mozambique. 

Besides an initiating and executive role in the projects, I was also known as main facilitator in participative processes and workshops, and last but not least, my visualization skills. 

Member account team Nature and account team International 
Member National Core team Wildfire

Winner Green Cube, Russian National Award on landscape architecture 2011 
(category Best Public conceptual plans; in consortium with OKRA, AMPIR and city of Moscow)
profile_positions.title: Senior Landscape Architect

profile_positions.title: Head of Company Emergency Response Team (Hoofd BHV)

profile_positions.description:
Until 2012, as Head of Design of the Region South (Provinces of Limburg, Brabant and Zeeland) of the Dutch Government Service for Land and Water management (DLG), I was also responsible for ensuring spatial quality, strategy and implementation, in terms of content and process. I had a role as supervisor, coach and inspirator in a team of 12 spatial designers, participated in in spatial strategic consultation on different levels and provided independent advice on quality of the different projects of DLG. In 2012 the different regional teams on Spatial Design merged to one central team, led by my present colleague at Alterra, Pieter Boone.   

DLG, the Dutch Government Service for Land and Water management, is an independent executive agency of the Dutch ministry of Economic Affairs.  DLG has over 75 years of experience in strategy development and policy implementation in the Dutch rural area and peri-urban areas. Developing coherent strategies throughout different policy levels and integrating different disciplines. Working on behalf of several government authorities at different levels, local, regional and national. In an international context, DLG carried out a wide variety of advisory and cooperative projects in a range of countries at the request of local and national authorities. DLG has built up broad networks on area development and land and water management, nature conservation and land consolidation. DLG has contributed to the development and implementation of different EU directives, mainly through EU Twinning projects. DLG also carried out bilateral Government to Government projects, and participates in other projects dealing with DLG’s core areas of work.
profile_positions.title: Head of Design -Region South

volunteer_experiences.description:
Winner Europa Nostra Award 2013 
Winner Knippenberg Award -Heritage & Landscape 2011

The Federation stands for a new future for the historic railway bridges (built c.1890) and the former railway track of the so-called ‘Halvezolenlijn’, between Geertruidenberg and s’-Hertogenbosch. . After decades of hard work the track is now used as a local pedestrian route, a regional cycling route, and the whole area partly as a city park. The natural surroundings of the railway track, the nature reserves, and cultural historical landscapes of the so-called ‘slagen’ landscape and the Moerputten, are open for hikers, bird watchers and other visitors. An interesting and important link has been created between cultural historical values, the values of the natural world, of recreation, and local and regional slow traffic. 

2013

“The Jury greatly appreciated the many aspects of this project as a combination of private and public initiatives in the fields of planning, infrastructure, nature conservation and heritage. The most eye catching part of the track is ‘the Moerputten’. Overall, not only have five historic bridges been conserved and put into excellent (but reversible) new uses – paths for both cyclists and pedestrians, offering an overview of the symbiosis of landscape, bridge and nature reserve - but also a strong and sustainable contribution has been made to the living environment of both people and nature.” (from jury report, EuropaNostra Award 2013)
